summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Health Services clinical encounter report for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, documenting an injury assessment following an incident in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYM) on July 23, 2019. The report details marks on his neck consistent with a rope, his statement that he did not know how the injury occurred, and his placement on suicide watch.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the medical report, found in his cell with a rope around his neck, assessed for injuries and placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Operational Lt.
persons.context: Requested the injury report; custody staff under their supervision found Epstein in his cell.

connections.description: Epstein is an inmate under the custody and supervision of the Operational Lieutenant and their staff.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit 205-Cell 124) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He was assessed by medical staff, showed a circular line of erythema on his neck, and was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical Assessment and Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein underwent a clinical encounter at Health Services. He was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling, but could not explain the marks on his neck. He was assessed for unspecified injury, ruled out self-inflicted injuries, and placed on suicide watch with follow-up planned.

keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor.
Epstein told medical staff he did not know how the injury occurred, stating 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting.' He could not explain the marks on his neck.

The medical examination revealed a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck, approximately 2 inches wide, covering two-thirds of the neck circumference, with signs of friction in the front.
Despite the injury, Epstein was documented as ambulatory, alert, oriented, smiling during the exam, and denying any pain, discomfort, or respiratory problems.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following this incident, with a plan for follow-up with psychology services.
